awd_titl_txt: Elucidating the molecular mechanism of DEMETER-mediated active DNA demethylation
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to advance the understanding of how genes important for nutrient accumulation in plant seeds are regulated. Seed production is vital for agriculture, biofuels, and human nutrition. Cereal grains account for over 50% of the world's dietary energy consumption and most of the grain nutrients are stored in a seed compartment called the endosperm. The project uses genetic, genomic, and computational tools to address fundamental seed biology questions, and provides interdisciplinary education and training opportunities for undergraduates, graduate students, and postdoctoral researchers. Undergraduate students will spend three summers in the laboratory and participate directly in the research activities in plant biology. This project will provide critical research experience for the undergraduates and important training for the graduate student and the postdoctoral fellow, thus developing a diverse, globally competitive workforce in this field.


Genomic imprinting influences seed yield by controlling resource allocation to the endosperm where the synthesis and storage of protein, starch, and lipid nutrients occurs. In flowering plants gene imprinting is established by DEMETER (DME) mediated active DNA demethylation. DME encodes a large polypeptide with multiple conserved domains, and except for the well-characterized glycosylase domain, very little is known about the function of the other domains. Elucidating how DME is regulated and directed to proper genomic locations is crucial to advance the knowledge on seed development, and can inspire development of novel molecular strategies for breeding or engineering desirable traits in important crop plants. This project aims to elucidate the roles of these conserved domains on DME activity and seed viability through molecular, genetic, genomic and epigenomic analyses. A novel bipartite model for structural and functional regulation for DME activity is proposed. Understanding why DME adopts modular catalytic and regulatory domain architecture and elucidating how linker histone H1 assists DME mediated active DNA demethylation will significantly increase the understanding of how epigenetic information is established and maintained in plants.

Award Title: Elucidating the Molecular Mechanism of DEMETER-Mediated Active DNA Demethylation

PI: Tzung-Fu Hsieh

Co-PI: Wenyan Xiao

Award Number: MCB-1715111

In 2017, North Carolina State University received a $ 557,461 NSF MCB award entitled ?Elucidating the Molecular Mechanism of DEMETER-Mediated Active DNA Demethylation? to study the function and regulation of an essential gene DEMETER during plant reproduction. The project focused on the following three objectives:

Define the function of DME domains in regulating DNA demethylation and seed viability in Arabidopsis?: The Arabidopsis DEMETER (DME) DNA glycosylase demethylates the central cell genome prior to fertilization. This epigenetic reconfiguration of the female gamete companion cell establishes gene imprinting in the endosperm and is essential for seed viability. However, how DME is targeted to various locations remains unknown. During the course of this project, we showed that the multi-domain DME is organized into two functional regions: The C-terminal region guides localization and catalysis whereas the N-terminus likely recruits chromatin remodelers to facilitate demethylation within heterochromatin. Within the catalytic CTD region, we found the CXXC domain is important for DME function in vivo, but not for DME enzymatic activity in vitro. When the CXXC domain is mutated, the mutant form of DME cannot effectively rescue the dme-induced seed abortion. We conclude although CXXC is critical for DME function, it is not likely to be needed for DME localization to its target sites. Another domain within the CTD region is the RRMF domain near the end of DME protein. We found that the predicted protein structure (using AlphaFold2) distantly resembles other histone binding domains. We are in the process of purifying CTD recombinant protein expressed in bacterial for future biochemical analysis.

Determine how linker histone H1 participates in DME-mediated active DNA demethylation: H1 linker histones are conserved eukaryotic nuclear proteins required to maintain higher order chromatin structure and DNA methylation patterns in plants and animals. H1.2 interacts with DME in a yeast two-hybrid screen. In the endosperm derived from a cross between female h1 triple mutant and wild-type pollen, the expression of selected DME-regulated imprinted genes was reduced and their maternal alleles methylation was increased, suggesting that H1 might play a role in mediating DME demethylation. We found that H1 loss resulted in endosperm hypomethylation, suggesting that the central cell chromatin is less condensed and more accessible by DME in the absence of H1. Maternal H1 loss differentially affected methylation pattern of canonical DME DMRs but did not substantially affect parent-of-origin specific expression of a list of reported imprinted genes.

Identify proteins that target DME to genomic loci and determine their roles in DME-mediated DNA demethylation: We used yeast two hybrid assay to screen for DME interaction proteins. We identified more than 20 potential DME interacting proteins. Unfortunately, none of the selected candidate gene mutant exhibited any seed abortion phenotype similar to the dme mutant. These results suggested yeast two hybrid assay is not an effect method for our purpose. We also used candidate gene approach in which we identified a list of histone acetylases that most likely function in the methylated DNA environment. However, none of the candidate genes we tested was involved in DME demethylation pathway. We searched for more effective ways to identify DME interaction proteins. Proximity-based labeling (PL) combined with subtractive mass spectrometry proteomics has emerged as a powerful complementary approach to classic affinity purification of multiprotein complexes. The approach allows for the capture and identification of both spatially and temporally associated proteins in the context of their native environment. We hope to continue this study in the near future.

Summary of results related to broader impacts: This project combined genetics, molecular and cellular biology, genomics, and computational analysis that provided interdisciplinary education and training opportunities for two postdoctoral fellows (NCSU), three graduate students (SLU), twelve undergraduates (SLU), one visiting scholar (NCSU), and three high school students (SLU). In addition, the PI's lab hosted a semester-long biotech intern, a biotechnology major in the local Rowan?Cabarrus Community College (RCCC), and trained her for plant care, genotyping, DNA isolation, PCR technique, and additional hands-on experiments. The internship training helped her secure a laboratory technician position at the Institute for In Vitro Sciences, Inc. (Gaithersburg, Maryland) immediately upon graduation. She has since been promoted to a Biologist II position in the same company. The project so far also contributed directly or indirectly to the training of three PI?s former postdocs who subsequently either obtained faculty position or continued in their academic careers (one Professor in Henan University, one postdoc in Danforth Plant Science Center, and one senior scientist in Montana State University). Two Co-PI?s PhD students, one is in the STEM industry and the other is a postdoc at Saint Louis University. Most undergraduates trained in Co-PI?s lab are now in graduate schools, other professional schools, or STEM industries.
